test_cases.title: Command-line arguments

assertion.stdout_match:
1st argument: Argument Number 1
2nd argument: Command line arg 2

test_cases.summary: Read command line arguments
test_cases.description: Read 2 command line arguments and print them out.

implementations.code:
echo "1st argument: $1"
echo "2nd argument: $2"

implementations.command: dotnet run arguments 'Argument Number 1' 'Command line arg 2'
go run arguments.go 'Argument Number 1' 'Command line arg 2'

implementations.code:
console.log("1st argument:", Deno.args[0])
console.log("2nd argument:", Deno.args[1])
implementations.command: deno run --allow-read --allow-write arguments.mjs 'Argument Number 1' 'Command line arg 2'

implementations.code:
console.log("1st argument:", process.argv[2])
console.log("2nd argument:", process.argv[3])

print("1st argument: "..arg[1])
print("2nd argument: "..arg[2])

<?php

echo "1st argument: ", $argv[1], "\n";
echo "2nd argument: ", $argv[2], "\n";

import sys

print("1st argument: " + sys.argv[1])
print("2nd argument: " + sys.argv[2])

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

cat("1st argument:", args[1], "\n")
cat("2nd argument:", args[2], "\n")

puts "1st argument: #{ARGV[0]}"
puts "2nd argument: #{ARGV[1]}"

implementations.command: cargo script arguments.rs 'Argument Number 1' 'Command line arg 2'

implementations.code:
import Foundation

let args = CommandLine.arguments

print("1st argument: \(args[1])")
print("2nd argument: \(args[2])")

test_cases.title: Null character
test_cases.summary: Output a null character to stdout
test_cases.description: See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Null_character

implementations.code: printf "Hello World \0"
console.log("Hello World \0")
console.log("Hello World \0")
print("Hello World \0")

<?php

echo "Hello World \0";
print("Hello World \0")

temp_file <- tempfile()

writeBin(c(charToRaw("Hello World "), as.raw(0), charToRaw("\n")), temp_file)

system(paste("cat", temp_file))

unlink(temp_file)

use v6;

say "Hello World \0";
puts "Hello World \0"
print("Hello World \0")

test_cases.title: Standard input

assertion.stdout_match:
line: hi
line: hello
line: how are you

test_cases.summary: Read from stdin line by line
test_cases.description:
Read one line at a time from stdin and print it.
This example assumes that all the input on stdin is available at once.

implementations.code:
while IFS= read -r user_input; do
  echo "line: $user_input"
done
implementations.command:
bash stdin.sh <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

dotnet run stdin <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

go run stdin.go <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

java Stdin.java <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

deno run --allow-read --allow-write stdin.mjs <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

node stdin.mjs <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

implementations.code:
for user_input in io.lines() do
    print("line: " .. user_input)
end
implementations.command:
lua stdin.lua <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

implementations.code:
<?php

while ($user_input = fgets(STDIN)) {
    echo "line: ", $user_input;
}
implementations.command:
php stdin.php <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

perl stdin.pl <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

python stdin.py <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

Rscript stdin.R <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

implementations.code:
use v6;

say "line: $_" for lines;
implementations.command:
raku stdin.raku <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

implementations.code:
while user_input = gets
  puts "line: #{user_input}"
end
implementations.command:
ruby stdin.rb <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

cargo script stdin.rs <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

swift stdin.swift <<EOF
hi
hello
how are you
EOF

test_cases.title: Streaming standard input
test_cases.summary: Stream from stdin line by line
test_cases.description:
Stream one line at a time from stdin and print it to stdout.

The test runner for this case will only provide the next line on stdin when the previous line has be printed to stdout.
This requires either that stdout is unbuffered or that stdout is flushed after each line is written to it.
Some languages do this automatically, other don't.

implementations.code:
while IFS= read -r user_input; do
  echo "received $user_input"
done

for user_input in io.lines() do
    print("received " .. user_input)
end

<?php

while ($user_input = fgets(STDIN)) {
    echo "received ", $user_input;
}

STDOUT.sync = true

while input = gets
  puts "received #{input}"
end

import Foundation

#if os(macOS) || os(iOS)
  import Darwin
#elseif os(Linux)
  import Glibc
#endif
setvbuf(stdout, nil, _IONBF, 0)

while let line = readLine() {
  print("received \(line)")
}

test_cases.title: Read text file

assertion.stdout_match:
line: hi
line: hello
line: how are you

test_cases.summary: Read a text file line by line
test_cases.description: Read one line at a time from a file called `my-text-file.txt` and print it.

implementations.code:
file_path="./my-text-file.txt"

while IFS= read -r line; do
  echo "line: $line"

done < "$file_path"

local filePath = "./my-text-file.txt"

local file = io.open(filePath, "r")

for line in file:lines() do
    print("line: " .. line)
end
file:close()

<?php

$file_path = './my-text-file.txt';

foreach (file($file_path) as $index => $line) {
    echo "line: $line";
}

file_path = './my-text-file.txt'

with open(file_path, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
    for line in file:
        line = line.strip()
        print(f"line: {line}")

use v6;

say "line: $_" for './my-text-file.txt'.IO.lines;

File.foreach("./my-text-file.txt") do |line|
  puts "line: #{line}"
end

test_cases.title: Write text file
test_cases.summary: Write to a text file
test_cases.description: Write the string `Hello World!` to a file named `output.txt`.

implementations.code: echo "Hello World!" > output.txt
await Deno.writeTextFile("output.txt", "Hello World!");

import fs from 'fs/promises'

await fs.writeFile("output.txt", "Hello World!")

local file = io.open("output.txt", "w")
file:write("Hello World!")
file:close()

<?php

file_put_contents("output.txt", "Hello World!");

outfile = "output.txt"
text = "Hello World!"

with open(outfile, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    f.write(text)
writeLines("Hello World!", "output.txt")
File.write "output.txt", "Hello World!"

import Foundation

try "Hello World!".write(toFile: "output.txt", atomically: false, encoding: .utf8)

test_cases.title: Build JSON array of numbers
test_cases.summary: Create and output a JSON array of numbers
test_cases.description:
Accept a list of strings as command line arguments.
Create and output a JSON array of the *lengths* of the strings.

implementations.code:
lengths=()

for arg in "$@"; do
  lengths+=("${#arg}")
done

jo -a "${lengths[@]}"
implementations.command: bash json_numbers.sh a bc def ghij
dotnet run json_numbers a bc def ghij
go run json_numbers.go a bc def ghij
java JsonNumbers.java a bc def ghij
deno run --allow-read --allow-write json_numbers.mjs a bc def ghij
node json_numbers.mjs a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
local cjson = require("dkjson")

local lengths = {}
for i = 1, #arg do
    table.insert(lengths, string.len(arg[i]))
end

print(cjson.encode(lengths))
implementations.command: lua json_numbers.lua a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
<?php

$myStrings = array_slice($argv, 1);

$stringLengths = array_map('strlen', $myStrings);

echo json_encode($stringLengths);
implementations.command: php json_numbers.php a bc def ghij
perl json_numbers.pl a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
import json
import sys


my_strings = sys.argv[1:]

string_lengths = [len(string) for string in my_strings]

print(json.dumps(string_lengths))
implementations.command: python json_numbers.py a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
library(jsonlite)

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

string_lengths <- sapply(args, nchar)

cat(toJSON(string_lengths))
implementations.command: Rscript json_numbers.R a bc def ghij
raku json_numbers.raku a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
require 'json'

my_strings = ARGV

string_lengths = my_strings.map(&:length)

puts JSON.generate(string_lengths)
implementations.command: ruby json_numbers.rb a bc def ghij
cargo script json_numbers.rs a bc def ghij
swift json_numbers.swift a bc def ghij

test_cases.title: Build JSON array of objects
test_cases.summary: Create and output a JSON array of objects
test_cases.description:
Accept a list of strings as command line arguments.
Create and output a JSON array of objects, one for each strings, where each
object has a key-value pair where the key is the uppercased string and the
value is the length of the string.

implementations.code:
json_objects=()

for arg in "$@"; do
    upper_arg=$(tr '[:lower:]' '[:upper:]' <<< "$arg")
    length=${#arg}
    json_objects+=("$(jo "$upper_arg"="$length")")
done

jo -a "${json_objects[@]}"

implementations.command: dotnet run json_object_array a bc def
go run json_object_array.go a bc def
deno run --allow-read --allow-write json_object_array.mjs a bc def

implementations.code:
<?php
$args = array_slice($argv, 1);

$myArray = array_map(function($arg) {
    return [strtoupper($arg) => strlen($arg)];
}, $args);

echo json_encode($myArray);

import json
import sys


args = sys.argv[1:]

my_array = [{arg.upper(): len(arg)} for arg in args]

print(json.dumps(my_array))

library(jsonlite)

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

myArray <- list()
for (arg in args) {
    string_length <- list()
    string_length[[toupper(arg)]] <- nchar(arg)
    myArray[[length(myArray)+1]] <- string_length
}

cat(toJSON(myArray, auto_unbox=TRUE))

require 'json'

my_strings = ARGV

my_array = my_strings.map { |string| {string.upcase => string.length} }

puts JSON.generate(my_array)

implementations.command: cargo script json_object_array.rs a bc def

test_cases.title: Build JSON object
test_cases.summary: Create and output a JSON object
test_cases.description:
Accept a list of strings as command line arguments.
Create and output a JSON object with the strings as keys and their lengths as values.

implementations.code:
json_object='{}'

for arg in "$@"; do
    length=${#arg}
    json_object=$(<<<"$json_object" jo -f - "$arg=$length")
done

echo "$json_object"
implementations.command: bash json_stdout_object.sh a bc def ghij
dotnet run json_stdout_object a bc def ghij
go run json_stdout_object.go a bc def ghij
java JsonStdoutObject.java a bc def ghij
deno run --allow-read --allow-write json_stdout_object.mjs a bc def ghij
node json_stdout_object.mjs a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
local cjson = require("dkjson")

local dict = {}

for i = 1, #arg do
    dict[arg[i]] = arg[i]:len()
end

print(cjson.encode(dict))
implementations.command: lua json_stdout_object.lua a bc def ghij

implementations.code:
<?php
$myStrings = array_slice($argv, 1);

$stringLengthDict = array_combine($myStrings, array_map('strlen', $myStrings));

echo json_encode($stringLengthDict);
implementations.command: php json_stdout_object.php a bc def ghij
perl json_stdout_object.pl a bc def ghij

import sys

my_strings = sys.argv[1:]

print(json.dumps(string_length_dict))

implementations.code:

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

for (string in args) {
  string_length[[string]] <- nchar(string)
}

cat(toJSON(string_length, auto_unbox = TRUE))

test_cases.title: Build JSON object of arrays of strings
test_cases.summary: Create and output a JSON object with arrays of strings as values
test_cases.description:
Accept a list of strings as command line arguments.
Create and output a JSON object with the strings as keys and arrays of their characters as values.

implementations.code:
json_object='{}'

for arg in "$@"; do
    upper_chars=$(<<<"$arg" tr '[:lower:]' '[:upper:]' | fold -w1)

    json_array=$(jo -a ${upper_chars[@]})

    # merge this object with the current object
    json_object="$(<<<"$json_object" jo -f - "$arg"="$json_array")"
done

echo "$json_object"

implementations.command: dotnet run json_object_with_array_values a bc def
go run json_object_with_array_values.go a bc def
deno run --allow-read --allow-write json_object_with_array_values.mjs a bc def

implementations.code:
local cjson = require("dkjson")

local string_letters_dict = {}

for i = 1, #arg do
    local string = arg[i]
    local letters = {}

    for letter in string:gmatch(".") do
        table.insert(letters, letter:upper())
    end
    string_letters_dict[string] = letters
end

print(cjson.encode(string_letters_dict))

<?php
$myStrings = array_slice($argv, 1);

$stringLettersDict = array_combine(
    $myStrings, array_map(
        fn($str) => str_split(strtoupper($str)), $myStrings
    )
);

echo json_encode($stringLettersDict);

import json
import sys

my_strings = sys.argv[1:]

string_letters_dict = {string: [s.upper() for s in string] for string in my_strings}

print(json.dumps(string_letters_dict))

library(jsonlite)

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

string_letters <- list()
for (string in args) {
  letters <- toupper(strsplit(string, split="")[[1]])
  string_letters[[string]] <- letters
}

cat(toJSON(string_letters))

require 'json'

my_strings = ARGV

string_letters_dict = my_strings.to_h { |string| [string, string.upcase.chars] }

puts JSON.generate(string_letters_dict)

implementations.command: cargo script json_object_with_array_values.rs a bc def

test_cases.title: JSON with control characters & emoji
test_cases.summary: Build and out output a JSON string containing control characters and emojis.
test_cases.description:
Receive a string as a command line argument and print it as the JSON string. The string is
`"hello \n \u0001 world "`.

See [JSON with null character](../json_null_char) for outputting the Null Character (`\0`) in a JSON string.

implementations.code: echo -n "$1" | jq -R -s .

const myString = Deno.args[0]

console.log(JSON.stringify(myString))

const myString = process.argv[2]

console.log(JSON.stringify(myString))

local cjson = require("dkjson")

print(cjson.encode(arg[1]))

<?php

$testString = $argv[1];

echo json_encode($testString);

import json
import sys

test_string = sys.argv[1]

print(json.dumps(test_string))

library(jsonlite)

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

cat(toJSON(args, auto_unbox = TRUE))

require 'json'

test_string = ARGV[0]

puts JSON.generate(test_string)

import Foundation

let testString = CommandLine.arguments[1]

let jsonData = try JSONEncoder().encode(testString)
print(String(data: jsonData, encoding: .utf8)!)

test_cases.title: JSON with null character
test_cases.summary: Create output JSON with a null character
test_cases.description:
In a JSON string the null character is represented as `\u0000`.

JSON strings are UTF-8 encoded, so the null character is valid, but
nevertheless, some JSON parsers cannot handle it.

implementations.code: printf "Hello World \0" | jq -R .
console.log(JSON.stringify("Hello World \0"))
console.log(JSON.stringify("Hello World \0"))

local json = require("dkjson")

print(json.encode("Hello World \0"))

<?php

echo json_encode("Hello World \0");

import json

print(json.dumps("Hello World \0"))

use JSON::Fast;

say to-json("Hello World \0");

require 'json'

puts "Hello World \0".to_json

import Foundation

let str = "Hello World \0"

let data = try JSONEncoder().encode(str)
print(String(data: data, encoding: .utf8)!)

test_cases.title: Output JSON
test_cases.summary: Create and output JSON
test_cases.description: Create and output JSON that contains a variety of data types.

implementations.code:
# jo can't handle the null character (\0) so we use jq to add it as a workaraound
object_with_nonascii_string='{  }'

jo \
  true=true \
  false=false  \
  zero=0 \
  int=42 \
  float=3.14 \
  null=null \
  -s "empty string"="" \
  -s "a string with non-ascii characters"=$'hello \n \1 world '

jo \
  "array of strings=$(
    jo -a abc def ghi jkl
  )" \
  "array of numbers=$(
    jo -a 13 42 9000 -7
  )" \
  "array of nothing=$(
    jo -a </dev/null
  )" \
  "array of mixed=$(
    jo -a 13 def null false "$(jo -a a)" "$(jo o=1)"
  )" \
  "array of objects=$(
    jo -a \
      "$(jo name="Bob Barker" age=84)" \
      "$(jo address1="123 Main St" address2="Apt 1")"
  )" \
  "array of arrays=$(
    jo -a \
      "$(jo -a a b c)" \
      "$(jo -a d e f)"
  )"

jo objects="$(
  jo nested="$(
    jo objects="$(
      jo are="supported"
    )"
  )"
)"

<?php

$firstJsonObject = [
    "true" => true,
    "false" => false,
    "zero" => 0,
    "int" => 42,
    "float" => 3.14,
    "null" => null,
    "empty string" => "",
    "a string with non-ascii characters" => "hello \n \x01 world "
];

$secondJsonObject = [
    "array of strings" => ["abc", "def", "ghi", "jkl"],
    "array of numbers" => [13, 42, 9000, -7],
    "array of nothing" => [],
    "array of mixed" => [13, "def", null, false, ["a"], ["o" => 1]],
    "array of objects" => [
        ["name" => "Bob Barker", "age" => 84],
        ["address1" => "123 Main St", "address2" => "Apt 1"]
    ],
    "array of arrays" => [
        ["a", "b", "c"],
        ["d", "e", "f"]
    ]
];

$thirdJsonObject = [
    "objects" => [
        "nested" => [
            "objects" => [
                "are" => "supported"
            ]
        ]
    ]
];

echo json_encode($firstJsonObject) . "\n";
echo json_encode($secondJsonObject) . "\n";
echo json_encode($thirdJsonObject) . "\n";

library(jsonlite)

first_json_object <- list(
  true = TRUE,
  false = FALSE,
  zero = 0,
  int = 42,
  float = 3.14,
  null = NA,
  "empty string" = "",
  "a string with non-ascii characters" = "hello \n \u0001 world "
)

second_json_object <- list(
  "array of strings" = c("abc", "def", "ghi", "jkl"),
  "array of numbers" = c(13, 42, 9000, -7),
  "array of nothing" = list(),
  "array of mixed" = list(13, "def", NA, FALSE, list("a"), list(o = 1)),
  "array of objects" = list(
    list(name = "Bob Barker", age = 84),
    list(address1 = "123 Main St", address2 = "Apt 1")
  ),
  "array of arrays" = list(
    c("a", "b", "c"),
    c("d", "e", "f")
  )
)

third_json_object <- list(
  objects = list(
    nested = list(
      objects = list(
        are = "supported"
      )
    )
  )
)

cat(
  toJSON(first_json_object,  auto_unbox = TRUE, pretty = FALSE),
  toJSON(second_json_object, auto_unbox = TRUE, pretty = FALSE),
  toJSON(third_json_object,  auto_unbox = TRUE, pretty = FALSE),
  sep="\n"
)

require 'json'

puts JSON.generate({
    "true" => true,
    "false" => false,
    "zero" => 0,
    "int" => 42,
    "float" => 3.14,
    "null" => nil,
    "empty string" => "",
    "a string with non-ascii characters" => "hello \n \u0001 world ",
})

puts JSON.generate({
    "array of strings" => ["abc", "def", "ghi", "jkl"],
    "array of numbers" => [13, 42, 9000, -7],
    "array of nothing" => [],
    "array of mixed" => [13, "def", nil, false, ["a"], { "o" => 1}],
    "array of objects" => [
        { "name" => "Bob Barker", "age" => 84 },
        { "address1" => "123 Main St", "address2" => "Apt 1" },
    ],
    "array of arrays" => [
        ["a", "b", "c"],
        ["d", "e", "f"],
    ],
})

puts JSON.generate({
    "objects" => { "nested" => { "objects" => { "are" => "supported" } } },
})

import Foundation

let firstJsonObject: [String: Any] = [
  "true": true,
  "false": false,
  "zero": 0,
  "int": 42,
  "float": 3.14,
  "null": NSNull(),
  "empty string": "",
  "a string with non-ascii characters": "hello \n \u{0001} world ",
]

let secondJsonObject: [String: Any] = [
  "array of strings": ["abc", "def", "ghi", "jkl"],
  "array of numbers": [13, 42, 9000, -7],
  "array of nothing": [],
  "array of mixed": [13, "def", NSNull(), false, ["a"], ["o": 1]],
  "array of objects": [
    ["name": "Bob Barker", "age": 84],
    ["address1": "123 Main St", "address2": "Apt 1"],
  ],
  "array of arrays": [
    ["a", "b", "c"],
    ["d", "e", "f"],
  ],
]

let thirdJsonObject: [String: Any] = [
  "objects": [
    "nested": [
      "objects": [
        "are": "supported"
      ]
    ]
  ]
]

func jsonString(from dictionary: [String: Any]) -> String {
  let jsonData = try! JSONSerialization.data(withJSONObject: dictionary, options: [])
  return String(data: jsonData, encoding: .utf8)!
}

print(jsonString(from: firstJsonObject))
print(jsonString(from: secondJsonObject))
print(jsonString(from: thirdJsonObject))

test_cases.title: Parse JSON file

assertion.stdout_match:
Hello, 84 year old Bob
Hello, 67 year old Tina
Hello, 98 year old Steven

test_cases.summary: Read and parse a JSON file
test_cases.description:
Read a JSON file called `people.json` that contains an array of JSON objects.
For each JSON object, print a greeting.

implementations.code:
file_path="people.json"

jq -c '.[]' "$file_path" | while IFS= read -r person; do
    age=$(echo "$person" | jq -r '.age')
    first_name=$(echo "$person" | jq -r '.first_name')
    echo "Hello, $age year old $first_name"
done

local json = require("dkjson")

local filePath = "people.json"

local file = io.open(filePath, "r")
local jsonString = file:read("*a")
file:close()

local people, pos = json.decode(jsonString, 1, nil)

for _, person in ipairs(people) do
    print(string.format("Hello, %d year old %s", person.age, person.first_name))
end

<?php

$jsonData = file_get_contents('people.json');

$people = json_decode($jsonData);

foreach ($people as $person) {
    echo "Hello, {$person->age} year old {$person->first_name}\n";
}

import json

json_file = "people.json"

with open(json_file, "r", encoding='utf-8') as f:
    people = json.load(f)

for person in people:
    print(f"Hello, {person['age']} year old {person['first_name']}")

require 'json'

people = JSON.load_file("people.json")

people.each do |person|
  puts "Hello, #{person['age']} year old #{person['first_name']}"
end

test_cases.title: Decode Base64
test_cases.summary: Decode a base64 string
test_cases.description: Accept a base64 encoded string as a command line argument, decode it, and print it out.

implementations.code:
encoded_string="$1"

base64 -d <<< "$encoded_string"

local base64 = require("base64")
print(base64.decode(arg[1]))

<?php

$encodedString = $argv[1];

echo base64_decode($encodedString);

import base64
import sys

encoded_string = sys.argv[1]

decoded_string = base64.b64decode(encoded_string).decode()

print(decoded_string)

library(base64enc)

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

decoded_string <- rawToChar(base64decode(args))

cat(decoded_string)

require 'base64'

encoded_string = ARGV[0]

puts Base64.decode64(encoded_string)

import Foundation

let encodedString = CommandLine.arguments[1]
let data = Data(base64Encoded: encodedString)
print(String(data: data!, encoding: .utf8)!)

test_cases.title: Encode Base64
test_cases.summary: Encode a string as base64
test_cases.description: Accept a string as a command line argument, encode it as Base64, then print it out.

implementations.code:
test_string="$1"

echo -n "$test_string" | base64

local base64 = require("base64")
print(base64.encode(arg[1]))

<?php

$stringToEncode = $argv[1];

echo base64_encode($stringToEncode);

import base64
import sys

test_string = sys.argv[1]

encoded_string = base64.b64encode(test_string.encode()).decode()

print(encoded_string)

library(base64enc)

args <- commandArgs(trailingOnly = TRUE)

encoded_string <- base64encode(charToRaw(args))

cat(encoded_string)

require 'base64'

test_string = ARGV[0]

puts Base64.encode64(test_string)

import Foundation

let data = CommandLine.arguments[1].data(using: .utf8)!
print(data.base64EncodedString())

test_cases.title: Streaming from named pipe
test_cases.summary: Stream from a named pipe line by line
test_cases.description:
Stream one line at a time from a named pipe (named `input.pipe`) and print it to stdout.
The test runner for this case will only provide the next line on the `input.pipe` when the previous line has be printed to stdout.

This requires either that stdout is unbuffered or that stdout is flushed after each line is written to it.
Some languages do this automatically, other don't.

implementations.code: tr '[:lower:]' '[:upper:]' < input.pipe

local input_file = io.open("input.pipe", "r")

for line in input_file:lines() do
    io.write(line:upper() .. "\n")
    io.flush()
end

input_file:close()

<?php

$input_pipe = fopen("input.pipe", 'r');

while (($line = fgets($input_pipe)) !== false) {
    echo strtoupper($line);
}

fclose($input_pipe);

import sys

pipe_in = "input.pipe"

with open(pipe_in, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as input_pipe:
    for line in input_pipe:
        sys.stdout.write(line.upper())
        sys.stdout.flush()

STDOUT.sync = true

File.foreach 'input.pipe' do |line|
  puts line.upcase
end

test_cases.title: Streaming to and from named pipes
test_cases.summary: Stream lines from a named pipe, write to another named pipe
test_cases.description:
Stream one line at a time from a named pipe (named `streaming-in.pipe`) and
print it to another named pipe (named `streaming-out.pipe`).

The test runner for this case will only provide the next line on stdin when the previous line has be printed to stdout.
This requires either that stdout is unbuffered or that stdout is flushed after each line is written to it.
Some languages do this automatically, other don't.

implementations.code:
while IFS= read -r line; do
    echo "received $line"
done < streaming-in.pipe > streaming-out.pipe

local output = io.open("streaming-out.pipe", "w")
local input = io.open("streaming-in.pipe", "r")

for line in input:lines() do
    output:write("received " .. line .. "\n")
    output:flush()
end

input:close()
output:close()

<?php

$output_pipe = fopen('streaming-out.pipe', 'w');
$input_pipe = fopen('streaming-in.pipe', 'r');

while (($line = fgets($input_pipe)) !== false) {
    fwrite($output_pipe, "received " . $line);
}

fclose($input_pipe);
fclose($output_pipe);

input_file = 'streaming-in.pipe'
output_file = 'streaming-out.pipe'

with open(input_file, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as input_pipe:
    with open(output_file, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as output_pipe:
        for line in input_pipe:
            output_pipe.write(f"received {line.strip()}\n")
            output_pipe.flush()

input <- file("streaming-in.pipe", "r")
output <- file("streaming-out.pipe", "w")

while (length(line <- readLines(input, n = 1)) > 0) {
  writeLines(paste("received", line), con = output)
  flush(output)
}

close(input)
close(output)

File.open 'streaming-out.pipe', 'w' do |output|
  output.sync = true

  File.foreach "streaming-in.pipe" do |line|
    output.puts "received #{line}"
  end
end

test_cases.title: Write to named pipe
test_cases.summary: Write text to a named pipe
test_cases.description:
Write `Hello World!` to a named pipe (named `output.pipe`).

When writing to named pipes, the program does not need to know it's a pipe,
but can treat it as a regular file when writing to it.

implementations.code: echo "Hello World!" > output.pipe

const encoder = new TextEncoder();

await Deno.writeFile("output.pipe", encoder.encode("Hello World!"));

import fs from 'fs/promises'

await fs.writeFile("output.pipe", "Hello World!")

local file = io.open("output.pipe", "w")
file:write("Hello World!")
file:close()

<?php

file_put_contents("output.pipe", "Hello World!");

outfile = "output.pipe"
text = "Hello World!"

with open(outfile, 'w', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    f.write(text)
writeLines("Hello World!", "output.pipe")
File.write "output.pipe", "Hello World!"

import Foundation

try "Hello World!".write(toFile: "output.pipe", atomically: false, encoding: .utf8)
